title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Progress Update 1
text:
Created a Quarto website project with a blog listing page and site pages (Home, About, Blog, Visualizations).
Rendered the site to the docs/ folder for GitHub Pages deployment.
Set up a GitHub repository for the final project and pushed the full site structure to main.
Resolved GitHub large file rejection by removing the large dataset from version control and adding a .gitignore to prevent future large data commits.
Created a reproducible project structure with data/, data_clean/, and scripts/ folders.
Added an initial Visualizations page and prepared it for publishing the first chart.
Next steps: clean a small dataset using a script, publish the first visualization with brief interpretation, and share the GitHub repo with a colleague for peer review.

title: Progress Update 1
text:
Created a Quarto website project with a blog listing page and site pages (Home, About, Blog, Visualizations).
Rendered the site to the docs/ folder for GitHub Pages deployment.
Set up a GitHub repository for the final project and pushed the full site structure to main.
Resolved GitHub large file rejection by removing the large dataset from version control and adding a .gitignore to prevent future large data commits.
Created a reproducible project structure with data/, data_clean/, and scripts/ folders.
Added an initial Visualizations page and prepared it for publishing the first chart.
Next steps: clean a small dataset using a script, publish the first visualization with brief interpretation, and share the GitHub repo with a colleague for peer review.

title: Visualizations
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.2
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

brexit_data <- read_csv("data/Brexit 5000 Sample Anonymized.csv")

New names:
Rows: 5000 Columns: 14
── Column specification
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr
(10): Commenter_ID, Comment_ID, Date, Brexit_Attitude, Commenter_Total_R... dbl
(4): ...1, Argument, Commenter_BA_Score, Chain_Comment
ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ
Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
• `` -> `...1`

colnames(brexit_data)

 [1] "...1"                           "Commenter_ID"                  
 [3] "Comment_ID"                     "Argument"                      
 [5] "Date"                           "Commenter_BA_Score"            
 [7] "Brexit_Attitude"                "Commenter_Total_Reactions"     
 [9] "Campaign"                       "Comment_Order"                 
[11] "Comment_Type"                   "Cross_Cutting_w_Counters"      
[13] "Cross_Cutting_without_Counters" "Chain_Comment"                 





summary(brexit_data$Commenter_BA_Score)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
-1.0000  0.9610  1.0000  0.6354  1.0000  1.0000     591 

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(brexit_data, aes(x = Commenter_BA_Score, fill = Cross_Cutting_w_Counters)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.4) +
  labs(
    title = "Aggression Distribution by Cross-Cutting Expression",
    x = "Behavioral Aggression Score"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: Removed 591 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_density()`).











Aggression is not limited to cross-cutting exchanges. Like-minded comments appear highly concentrated at the upper end of the aggression scale, suggesting that emotional intensity may be amplified within ideologically aligned groups. Cross-cutting discussions show more variation, indicating that disagreement alone does not necessarily drive hostility.





library(ineq)

counts <- brexit_data %>% count(Commenter_ID)
ineq(counts$n, type = "Gini")

[1] 0.1492548

brexit_data %>%
  count(Commenter_ID, sort = TRUE) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(Commenter_ID, n), y = n)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Most Active Participants",
    x = "Participant ID",
    y = "Number of Comments"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()










Participation is highly unequal. A small number of users contribute a disproportionately large share of comments, while most participants are far less active. This suggests that online political discourse may be shaped primarily by a vocal minority rather than broad engagement.

counts <- brexit_data %>% count(Commenter_ID)
ineq(counts$n, type = "Gini")

[1] 0.1492548

brexit_data %>%
  count(Commenter_ID, sort = TRUE) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(Commenter_ID, n), y = n)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Most Active Participants",
    x = "Participant ID",
    y = "Number of Comments"

Participation is highly unequal. A small number of users contribute a disproportionately large share of comments, while most participants are far less active. This suggests that online political discourse may be shaped primarily by a vocal minority rather than broad engagement.
